title: How people Covid area Interactive map reveals UKs new hotspots
story: Share this article Admissions rates have increased among all age groups, but are highest among over-85s, at 118.8 per 100,000 people, up nearly a quarter in a week.Pressure is mounting on health chiefs to speed up the rollout of fourth Covid vaccine doses to the vulnerable to counter rising admissions.No10's vaccine advisory panel recommended last month that over-75s, care home residents and patients with weakened immune system should be given the top-up shots around six months after their original booster.It is almost exactly six months since the last booster rollout was launched, and despite hospital admissions and cases on the rise again the NHS is still yet to send any invite anyone to come forward for their fourth vaccine in England. There is not yet a consensus on why Covid cases have started to rise across the UK again but, as well as behavioural changes, the rise of the BA.2 subvariant is thought to be playing a role.The mutant virus, which is around 30 per cent more infectious than the original Omicron, is dominant across the UK after outstripping its parent strain in a matter of weeks, after first appearing in England in January.BA.2 made up 88.3 per cent of cases in England by March 6, according to a report by the UK Health Security Agency published today, up from 52.1 per cent on February 20.Experts insist BA.2 is just as mild as Omicron and is not more likely to lead to hospitalisation. But the UKHSA has noted a small number of people who have been reinfected with BA.2 after recovering from Omicron. Other studies have pointed to the subvariant being significantly more immune-resistant than the original Omicron, which would make it easier to infect vaccinated or previously infected people.  Whitehall sources told The Times earlier this week that they had not seen any evidence of significant changes in behaviour. But Government adviser Professor Stephen Reicher, a behavioural scientist on SAGE, told MailOnline that there was a growing impression that Covid is 'yesterday's news' and causing people to be more lax.He claimed that even people who wanted to take precautions were being forced into more risky behaviours because the majority of restrictions have been lifted. But a number of experts, including Dr Simon Clarke, a microbiologist at the University of Reading, believe the uptick in cases and hospital admissions is the early sign of waning booster immunity.The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation (JCVI) last month recommended fourth doses to the most vulnerable age groups this spring, telling ministers they should be dished out around six months after their last vaccine. JCVI advisers originally recommended third doses on September 14, with over-75s, care home residents and patients with serious underlying health conditions first in the queue. Pfizer's booster drops from 90 per cent effectiveness against severe disease from Omicron to around 75 per cent after 10 weeks, according to the latest data.

title: cramping my style street art that highlights london living conditions in pictures
story: His street art, Brickflats, reflects the cramped living conditions many endure. Vangelis finds a wall with a brick missing, then fills the space with a resin-cast box that has figures of people squashed in. The first appeared last year, and so far nearly a dozen of his colourful bricks have been spotted in the capital, sometimes appearing overnight. Vangelis hopes his work is “a nice piece of art in a boring brick wall”, and that it will make people think: “This character looks a bit uncomfortable in that little box.”

title: england v ireland six nations live
story: “Class effort from the boys, I couldn’t ask of anything more from them. We rally wanted to make it right for Ewelsy and the forwards did an incredible job, for the vast majority of the game we managed to bully them.”They certainly did, Nora. An incredible effort that discombobulated Ireland for large parts of the game.I thought it was great game, which by no definition could be classed as ruined. Again, I disagree, that was objectively a good game of rugby.  Also, it’s not the laws’ or the ref’s fault that Charlie Ewels decided to tackle upright with force - something all coaches and tackling players have been told is a no-no for the best part of three years. Maybe Eddie Jones much hyped talk of physicality in the build up backfired on his own team?But, because rules, Jamison Gibson-Park has been given it.Sexton adds the two points.I didn’t say they went on to win, I said there’s not a lot of evidence the games are ruined.Sometimes sport is an emotional game, and England’s emotions and running rampant over Ireland at the moment.Frankly, even with England’s huge emotional commitment here, Ireland’s issues are much of their own making.“This game has been ruined as a contest after 90 seconds. 80,000 people in the stadium. Millions watching around the world. Red cards should mean player permanently excluded and team a man down for 15mins. Can then bring on a replacement.”  I respectfully disagree, Christopher. For the main reason that I don’t believe red cards ruin games if you look at the evidence of the actual games they happen in as this one has also demonstrated. Plus, red card offences should have a significant impact on a team, they are the most egregious infringements in the game.Smith tees it up again and this time slots it.And another penalty as Iain Henderson enters a maul from the side at the next lineout. The noise is high in Twickenham as the crowd sense something happening here.Smith steps up and gets his side on the board.Ireland will need to not let hubris set in here in the midst of this conspicuously unusual start.  In the latest bad news for England, Tom Curry is limping off to be replaced by Alex Dombrandt.But, it looks like Ringrose fumbled it forward at the base of a previous ruck. No Try. However, that passage showed England have a great deal to worry about when Ireland get on the front foot.England have a scrum on the Ireland 10m line as they try to sort out just what the hell they do from here in. The first thing is they’ve put Jack Nowell into the openside flank.Sexton can’t slot the extras from out wide.At the end of all that, Sexton kicks the penalty to put Ireland ahead.Ryan is being looked at, and the Ref wants a good look at the tackle...Courtney Lawes then leads out England to a swell of noise.  Eddie Jones has confirmed that Itoje is recovered and definitely starting. Andy Farrell has refused to be drawn on the Jones’s midweek kidology, meeting questions with a wall of PR speak about “process” and the like.“He has what Liam Neeson might call a very particular set of skills – skills acquired over a very long career.” Andy Bull takes a look at Peter O’Mahony’s role today. Why not send them my way by email or on TwitterLast minute bugs-going-around news aside Joe Marchant is in outside centre, Elliot Daly takes a seat on the bench. In the pack, Jamie George starts at hooker while Sam Simmonds starts at No 8 ahead of bench-bound Alex Dombrandt. Can’t help but feel this is the proper ‘international arrival’ opportunity to Simmonds, but will he take it?  Jamie Blamire and Joe Launchbury also return to the matchday squad, both on the bench. Ireland played Italy last time out, so there’s changes aplenty, but this certainly has more than a whiff of what Farrell considers to be his first choice team at present.  One of the most fascinating things about the Six Nations is that the low number of fixtures imbues the result of so many game with much importance. Like a reverse-baseball season. This match is not only a massive clash because of all it brings in its own right, but there is a lot riding on it for both teams. England lose this and they head to Paris next week with the real possibility of only two tournament match victories - a win changes the whole complexion of the year for them. This is not lost on Eddie Jones who has spent all week with his mindgames settings all the way up to eleven, calling Ireland “the most cohesive side in the world” while throwing shade that they “haven’t played a game as physical as this in a long time”. Andy Farrell, a man who spent the majority of his playing career in the unstoppable behemoth of the 1990s Wigan RLFC team, will have little trouble dealing with the mentality that is required when favourites. Ireland need a win to maintain maximum pressure on France and also to cement their position as clearly in the top two in Europe alongside Les Bleus with daylight before the rest hone into view.  On form and personnel Ireland should win this in a way not unlike that which despatched England in Dublin last year. But this is Twickenham, away wins are not easy to come by here and the home team have yet to put in what constitutes a real performance yet. Today would be a good time.

title: over one third of north s population hold irish passport
story: Observers have suggested the surge in Irish passport applications, against a decline in British, was due to pragmatism among the North’s unionists since the UK withdrew from the EU.  More than a third of Northern Ireland’s population hold an Irish passport, according to latest official figures.While applications plunged amid overseas travel restrictions during pandemic lockdowns, fresh data from the Department of Foreign Affairs shows numbers rebounding.Already this year, 24,643 people were issued with Irish passports in the North through Northern Ireland Passport Express (NIPX), which is available at post offices in the North. This is more than 400 every day. The figures do not include Irish citizens in the North who apply for their passports directly from Dublin.If the trend continues it suggests more than 150,000 Irish passports would be issued in the North by the year end.This would eclipse, dramatically, the 107,937 issued through NIPX in 2019 – the last full-year figure before coronavirus prevented international travel for most.Issued passports during 2019 in the North soared 27 per cent from the previous year (84,855). This continued a pattern of rising Irish passport applications in the region against declining British applications following Brexit. Official figures show there were 110,506 applications from Northern Ireland for a UK passport in 2019. This was down from 119,298 the previous year, in a continuing 15 per cent slide in such applications from people in the North over a five-year period.LockdownDespite the virus grounding most of the world’s aircraft since the outbreak began, 56,709 Irish passports were issued in the North last year, up almost 16 per cent from 48,911 in 2020, when the first pandemic lockdown was imposed in Ireland.Aggregate figures for the decade 2012 to 2022, to date, show 660,427 Irish passports issued in the North, about 35 per cent of the region’s 1.8 million population. Under the Belfast Agreement, Irish and British governments recognise the birthright of all people in Northern Ireland to identify as either Irish, British or both. There is also a right to dual citizenship and people can carry Irish and British passports. Observers have suggested the surge in Irish passport applications, against a decline in British, is down to increasing pragmatism among the North’s unionists since the United Kingdom withdrew from the European Union. An Irish passport allows them to travel freely within the EU. The Democratic Unionist Party’s Sammy Wilson has previously said he gets “quite a lot” of loyalist voters in his constituency who ask him to sign off on their applications for Irish passports. The East Antrim MP said he encourages constituents going on holidays to opt for an Irish passport as it is a quicker process and negates restrictions imposed on British citizens in the EU as a result of Brexit.Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: scientists saving worlds banana crop
story: The 1943 Louis Prima hit “Yes! We Have No Bananas” became the unofficial theme tune for rationing during the Second World War when the Ministry of Food banned the import of the fruit to save ships.But now scientists have found a way to make sure bananas remain on grocery shelves.Cambridge University has discovered how to graft species of banana together to transfer beneficial characteristics, such as disease resistance - a task that was believed impossible before now “I read back over decades of research papers on grafting and everybody said that it couldn’t be done,” said Dr Greg Reeves, a Gates Cambridge Scholar in the University of Cambridge Department of Plant Sciences, and first author of the paper.“I was stubborn enough to keep going - for years - until I proved them wrong.”The breakthrough comes at a crucial time when banana plantations are under threat from soil-borne pathogens including Panama disease which has been destroying drops for over 30 years.A recent acceleration in the spread of this disease has prompted fears of global banana shortages.Single variety vulnerable to diseaseThe world’s banana industry is based on a single variety, called the Cavendish banana - a clone that can withstand long-distance transportation, but has no genetic ersity, making it vulnerable to disease. Cavendish bananas are also sterile so disease resistance cannot be bred into future generations of the plant. Until now it was thought impossible to graft grass-like plants in the group known as monocotyledons because they lack a specific tissue type, called the vascular cambium, in their stem.But scientists have found that when tissue is still embryonic in seeds, it can fuse sufficiently with a different species, allowing for grafting. It means that species can be combined without the need for genetic modification. “We’ve achieved something that everyone said was impossible, said Professor Julian Hibberd in the University of Cambridge’s Department of Plant Sciences, senior author of the report.“We found that even distantly related species, separated by deep evolutionary time, are graft compatible.Grafting embryonic tissue holds real potential across a range of grass-like species.Technique transferrable to other plants There are an estimated 60,000 plants that are monocotyledons, including food staples like rice, wheat and barley. Being able to add helpful traits could bring huge benefits to the food industry. The team has also shown it works in pineapple, onion, tequila agave and date palm by injecting fluorescent dye into the plant roots – from where it was seen to move up the plant and across the graft junction.“It’s an urgent challenge to make important food crops resistant to the diseases that are destroying them,” added Dr Reeves.“Our technique allows us to add disease resistance, or other beneficial properties like salt-tolerance, to grass-like plants without resorting to genetic modification or lengthy breeding programmes.”The researchers have filed a patent for their grafting technique through Cambridge Enterprise. “Panama disease is a huge problem threatening bananas across the world. It’s fantastic that the University of Cambridge has the opportunity to play a role in saving such an important food crop,” said Dr Louise Sutherland, Director Ceres Agri-Tech, a collaboration between Cambridge, four other universities and three agricultural research institutes.The research was published in the journal Nature.More from NewsOxford and Cambridge to &#39return looted Benin Bronzes to Nigeria within months&#39Russia-Ukraine latest: Vladimir Putin shows &#39no willingness&#39 to end war, warns France Equalities watchdog launches study aiming to ‘reduce distress’ in trans debatePoland says it ‘can’t take any more’ Ukrainian refugees and asks for international relocation systemCharity Commission bans group which claimed to successfully treat cancer with juice drinksDuke and Duchess of Cambridge to follow in Queen&#39s footsteps with first Caribbean tourMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: did britains zero covid policy blight generation lifetime
story: In normal times, there is a shocking poverty gap when it comes to how our children do at school. By the time they arrive for their very first day, disadvantaged kids are already four months’ learning behind their more privileged peers. Yet these are not normal times. Two years of Covid shutdowns have led to educational consequences that grimly rival those of a deprived upbringing – but for all.After the first lockdown, for example, the latest data suggests average primary school pupils were 3.6 months adrift of the level in maths that pre-pandemic years had achieved at the same stage. Children in some parts of the country fared far worse. In Yorkshire and the Humber, the gap was 5.7 months. When it came to reading, primary children unlucky enough to find themselves in the Covid cohort were on average just under two months behind. The question now for teachers, parents and the Government is whether they will ever catch up, or whether the years of disruption they have encountered today will cascade through the rest of their lives, impacting university and career prospects and their personal lives, too. It was never meant to be like this. But temporary emergency measures have morphed into a two-year trial, with repeated lockdowns, homeschooling, and the pingdemic puncturing entire class bubbles. Still, it goes on.In January, almost one in 12 teachers was off work. Last week, MPs declared the Government’s £5 billion National Tutoring Programme to help disadvantaged children “level up” after Covid to be a costly failure. Meanwhile, according to the Centre for Social Justice, 100,000 “ghost children” – those who miss more than half their school sessions – have almost entirely disappeared from education since last year’s return to schools.Making good will not be easy. Deprived children may start school only four months behind, but generally they don’t catch up. According to Natalie Perera, CEO of the Education Policy Institute (EPI), by the time they leave education, the gap has widened to 18 months. So will Britain’s Covid cohort suffer a similar fate?The stakes for them, and the nation, could hardly be higher. Work by the Institute for Fiscal Studies suggests that every extra year of schooling adds eight per cent to lifetime earnings. Other studies put the figure even higher, between 10 and 15 per cent. Using these estimates, the EPI has calculated that Britain’s Covid cohort is likely to lose between £15,604 and £30,881 each over their careers. Pessimistic scenarios put the loss as high as £46,321 per child – adding up to £463 billion for all affected children in England. The World Bank calculates that, globally, such Covid-inflicted salary losses could add up to an astonishing $10 trillion (£7.6 trillion).Nor are the impacts on children purely academic, or their consequences solely financial. Repeated lockdowns are likely to take a significant toll on young people’s physical health given that, in 2019, a study suggested that people were 6.85 per cent less likely to report poor health in later life for one additional year of schooling.Meanwhile, surveyed by the charity Young Minds, two-thirds of children said they expected repeated lockdowns to leave long-term scars on their mental health. This is borne out by teachers who have seen children regress, not just in their studies, but in their social behaviour. Suddenly, the function of classrooms not just as places of learning, but of pastoral care, has become all too evident.Many places saw a rise in children referred to social services. In Middlesbrough, the number rose by 40 per cent year on year. As Amanda Spielman, Ofsted’s Chief Inspector, wrote in her recent annual report: “This was a difficult year to be young, and a challenging time to be learning. In all phases of education in 202021, most children and young people have learned less than they normally would have done. For many, the loss of education, disrupted routine and lack of physical and other activities led to physical and mental health problems. Loneliness, boredom and misery became endemic among the young.”After a wide-ranging survey, the Children’s Commissioner compiled some heartbreaking tales. One 10-year-old boy confessed: “My reading and spelling is not very good. All the words get muddled up and I need more help in class, but I can’t always have it.” A nine-year-old girl added: “Lockdown really stops children, because they can’t do that much stuff we love and it makes them go all shaky.”Some children will never have known anything else: six-year-olds now in Year 2 might be forgiven for forgetting the brief spell of normality they enjoyed after joining Reception in September 2019. By the following March, their educational landscape was blasted by the first lockdown their Year 1 was shattered by its successor in spring 2021. Headteachers are faced with pupils far behind usual developmental milestones: five- and six-year-olds in nappies isolated four- and five-year-olds, shorn of pre-school playdates, group childcare, contact with grandparents, and confronted by a world wearing masks, arriving on their first day with few words to express themselves, and boiling with frustration in consequence. The Education Endowment Foundation (EEF) found that more than three quarters of primary schools said pupils starting school in September 2020 needed more support with communication than in previous years. Isolated in the pandemic, with fewer opportunities for play, toddlers tested in the past two years for language, puzzle-solving and motor skills are far behind those tested last decade. “Things just began sort of falling off a rock,” said one scientist studying infant cognition.The damage may even be starting in the womb. The journal Nature recently reported on research suggesting that “pandemic-related stress during pregnancy could be negatively affecting foetal brain development”.Despite all this, there is cause for hope. Children – particularly young children – are rubbery creatures, with “bounceback-ability”. Researchers are confident that slow-starting toddlers can catch up. And at primary school age, too, the data shows that children released from lockdowns have pegged back some of their losses. By the end of last academic year, the average lag in maths had fallen from the 3.6 months of autumn 2020, to 2.2 months. Yorkshire and the Humber, which had fallen almost half a year behind, had recovered 3.8 months. Recovery is possible. Indeed, children have been shown to bounce back before, as they did after rural communities and schooling were hit (though much less severely) by the foot-and-mouth outbreak of 2001. They can overcome social barriers, too. In 1975, the psychologist Edward Tronick conducted the famous “Still Face” experiment which showed how toddlers of parents instructed to remain expressionless first courted their attention, then turned inward and withdrew. Repeating the experiment almost half a century later, this time with facemasks, did not produce the same results. The children were able to feed off other cues to communicate and bond. Older children, however, struggle more to recover. Secondary school children, who quickly fell behind an average of 1.5 months in reading after the first lockdown, have barely made up any lost ground after returning to class. It is tempting to tell parents that this is no problem – that all children are facing the same challenges and suffering the same setbacks. Yet study after study suggests this is not true. The gap between those who were homeschooled by well-educated, WFH parents with plenty of time, money and laptops and those who weren’t is growing wider and wider. Teachers struggle to  the ever-widening spectrum of ability they see in a single class. Those with funds flee to private schools, only entrenching inequality. The EPI is calling for a host of targeted measures – better early-years teachers, one-to-one tuition for struggling children, and afterschool activities rather than an extension of the school day, which might involve catch-up lessons but could simply be about socialising and sports.But it will take money. Total funding for education recovery in England now stands at £4.9 billion, or around £490 per pupil. That is considerably less than the Netherlands, say, where the figure is £2,100 per pupil. To truly make up for lost ground, the EPI suggests the Government will need to splash out another £8.6 billion.It is a sliding doors moment, with a generation’s education at stake. The consequences a bad start at school can have are clear: doing less well in exams, dropping out earlier, earning less, getting sicker and dying younger. “The pandemic has and will have a very considerable impact,” says Perera. “Time out of school has a long-term impact on employment outcomes as well as social and emotional health. We can’t say that they’ll never catch up, but what we do want is for the Government to acknowledge this and to provide more funding. The last thing we want to do is write this generation off.”More from NewsPriests escort humanitarian convoy into besieged Ukrainian city of MariupolOxford and Cambridge to &#39return looted Benin Bronzes to Nigeria within months&#39Russia-Ukraine latest: Vladimir Putin shows &#39no willingness&#39 to end war, warns France Equalities watchdog launches study aiming to ‘reduce distress’ in trans debatePoland says it ‘can’t take any more’ Ukrainian refugees and asks for international relocation systemCharity Commission bans group which claimed to successfully treat cancer with juice drinksMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: nicola sturgeons childish attention seeking proves scotland
story: One senses that Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s First Minister, misses the limelight she grabbed when Covid-19 was at its zenith. She seems instead to seek other means to keep her name before the public. It might be better for all, however, if she did so in a way that did not risk provoking the Third World War.Last week she showed her absence of statesmanship by demanding Nato “keep its mind open” on a no fly zone over Ukraine. The clear effect of such a zone, as even 14-year old armchair generals realise, would be that if a Russian jet flew into that airspace a Nato one would have to shoot it down. All right-thinking people feel nothing but revulsion for what the Russians are doing to Ukraine. But a no-fly zone could become a war between a nuclear-armed Nato and a nuclear-armed Russia: and no-one can so sure that the psychopath, sadist and narcissist who runs Russia would not launch such a weapon – unless, of course, he has taken Ms Sturgeon into his confidence.Normally, when Scotland’s First Minister says something absurd, her political opponents hesitate to take her on. Happily, this was not the Conservative Party’s response this time, as it realised the lethal consequences of her idiocy. Ministers are at last prepared to expose just how far out of her depth she is. Alister Jack, the Secretary of State for Scotland, was right to call her remarks “utterly irresponsible”. The Ministry of Defence has briefed the Scottish government regularly on the situation, yet what Ms Sturgeon suggested was at odds with what Admiral Sir Tony Radakin, Chief of the Defence Staff, had advised the Cabinet.There is a further paradox: although Ms Sturgeon seems willing to provoke the Third World War, she also wants to scrap the Trident missiles that would give the United Kingdom and her Nato allies a reasonable chance of avoiding the apocalypse. But because the Government at Westminster opposes a no-fly zone, for eminently sensible reasons, she seems to feel she has to call for one, just as during the pandemic she had to implement restrictions that began earlier, finished later, and were just that little bit more draconian. Like a spoilt child in a playground, she always has to be different, because in her ignorance she believes different is the same as better, and she has always to be better than the English oppressor.Similarly, as those she claims to represent struggle with increased energy bills, she opposes more drilling in the North Sea: frankly, if she really cared for their interests, she would sanction it tomorrow, and re-open some of Scotland’s coalmines too. Instead, her other concern last week was to apologise to the 4,000 or so people (about 15 per cent of whom were men) charged with Witchcraft under the Scottish Witchcraft Act of 1563, which she branded “injustice on a colossal scale”. She now advocates pardons for them, as she introduces an Orwellian law to make misogyny a criminal offence. Her only regret must be that the Act pre-dates the Act of Union, and all the great witch hunts also happened before 1707: otherwise one presumes the English taxpayer would be ordered to pay reparations.This desperate attention-seeking is another sign that peak Sturgeon has long passed: and it is harmless in that it diminishes only her and the fundamentally unserious cause of Scottish independence which she represents. And that cause will remain unserious so long as Ms Sturgeon and her acolytes act in such a petulant and irresponsible fashion.However, trying to pretend she understands international statesmanship is a more perilous activity, and one that shows her deeply unfit to lead. A period of silence, as Mr Attlee once put it, would be not only welcome, but perhaps life-saving. More from NewsPriests escort humanitarian convoy into besieged Ukrainian city of MariupolOxford and Cambridge to &#39return looted Benin Bronzes to Nigeria within months&#39Russia-Ukraine latest: Vladimir Putin shows &#39no willingness&#39 to end war, warns France Equalities watchdog launches study aiming to ‘reduce distress’ in trans debatePoland says it ‘can’t take any more’ Ukrainian refugees and asks for international relocation systemCharity Commission bans group which claimed to successfully treat cancer with juice drinksMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: adorable jack russell no eyes
story: Adorable Jack Russell with no eyes in desperate need of new homeSix-year-old Polly is currently up for adoption with Blind Dog Rescue UK and is hoping to secure a new home with loving owners committed to showing her the world through sound and scentPolly had to have both of her eyes removed Image: Blind Dog Rescue UKByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsAfter having her eyes surgically removed, little Polly became closed off to the world around her - and now needs an owner to help her out of her shell.The six-year-old dog had to have both of her eyes removed due to glaucoma, a group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve. Glaucoma is a very painful condition in dogs which cannot be cured but most cases can be well managed with eye drops and other medications.However, the Jack Russell wasnapost so lucky and had to have her eyes removed, making her completely blind. Despite her disability, Polly is a happy and confident little dog who enjoys spending time with humans and other animals.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Up for adoption with Blind Dog Rescue UK, she is currently in foster care in Northumberland but can be rehomed anywhere in the UK. A spokesperson from the charity said Please meet sweet little Polly who has just come into our care. She is currently in foster with another small dog who she gets on well with. Polly is amazing - she’s always lived with cats, brilliant with children and adults, also fine with other dogsshe knows they are approaching. Little Polly has an unknown allergy which makes her skin itchy and is currently on hypoallergenic food and takes daily tablets to keep it under control.Blind Dog Rescue UK works to rehome blind and partially sighted dogs who have been subjected to the “worst of humanity yet still have an astonishing capacity to adapt, love and become perfect ambassadors for blind dogs everywhere”. Many of the dogs in their care have been victims of abuse, neglect, disease or trauma - and struggle to survive in shelters. A Blind Dog Rescue UK statement reads: “It is incredibly dficult for sighted dogs to survive anyof time in these shelters let alone blind or partially sighted dogs. “We need to get to these dogs quickly and secure their immediate release and treatment.  “These dogs may have been deliberately blinded, involved in road traffic accidents or long term sufferers of painful conditions such as glaucoma.“They need veterinary care and to be given the safety and comfort of a foster home in which to start healing. “Here they are given love and affection and a warm bed - possibly the first they will have experienced in their letimes. At this point we are able to start assessing and promoting these wonderful dogs for forever homes.To adopt Polly, or find out more information about him, contact Blind Dog Rescue UK via their website www.bdruk.org.Do you have a story to sell  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TeamDogsDogsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: 12 cronies allies donors boris
story: cronies, allies and donors Boris Johnson has handed gongs to at top of societyBoris Johnson has handed out honours to a string of allies, Tory donors and cronies during his time in Downing StreetPrime Minister Boris Johnson Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByDan BloomOnline Political EditorLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political EditorBen Glaze:,  Mar |commentsBoris Johnson has come under fresh scrutiny over claims he pushed for a Russian-born crony to get a peerage despite security concerns. The Prime Minister said it was simply incorrect and would obviously be extraordinaryhe had intervened to secure a gong for Lord Lebedev. But the claims reignited the row over the numbers of allies who have received gongs from the PM. Labour have demanded a “post-appointment assessment” to examine the contributions of peers the Prime Minister places in the Lords. Here we look at some of allies, cronies and Tory donors who have been handed top gongs. Evgeny Lebedev  The Prime Minister made Evgeny Lebedev, the media mogul and son of billionaire ex-KGB agent Alexander, Lord Lebedev of Siberia at the height of Covid in . The ex-London mayor had for years been a guest at parties hosted by the socialite who owns the Evening Standard. As Foreign Secretary Mr Johnson declared an “overnight stay” with Evgeny Lebedev on  April . Reports later claimed the future Prime Minister had gone to Palazzo Terranova in Perugia for a “weekend-long party - and was spotted dishevelled and without his security detail at San Francesco d’Assisi airport the next day. Claims emerged this week that intelligence officials had raised concerns about the gong - leading the House of Lords Appointments Commissionto advise against it.But a source told the Sunday Times Boris Johnson then personally intervened - meeting Lebedev in person while he was dithering over a lockdown - and that “particular quite damning bit of advice” was later withdrawn.Mr Johnson has insisted it is “simply incorrect” that he personally or directly asked for the advice to be reversed. Lord Lebedev has not spoken in the Lords since his maiden speech, and Insider revealed he had only attended the Lords three times - narrowly missing the six-month absence that triggers an automatic suspension.On Friday, Lord Lebedev, who holds British citizenship, released a statement, saying he was not some agent of Russia .The peer acknowledged that his father was a long time ago a KGB officer but denied being a security risk to this country Jo Johnson  On just one day two years ago, Boris Johnson put his former boss, a billionaire Tory donor, a former top aide and a Brexiteer cricketer in the House of Lords for le . But the most striking name in his peers’ list of  July  was that of Jo Johnson - his own brother. The long-awaited list was snuck out on a hot Friday afternoon, hours after an important Covid announcement. Its huge size was branded a mockery of democracy and slammed by the Lordsapos own Speaker.Jo Johnson stood down as an MP at the  election and resigned as a minister, saying he was torn between family loyalty and the national interest over his brother’s hardline approach to Brexit.David Harding The billionaire, who has donated large sums to the Conservative Party, was handed a knighthood in the  New Year Honours.Hedge fund boss David Harding was knighted for “services to philanthropy”. The -year-old’s gts to science and mathematics programmes include £million to Cambridge University in  - the largest ever single donation by a Brit to a UK university.However, he is also a major donor to the Conservative Party, having pumped more than £.million into the Tory war chest since . Sir David, who founded investment management firm Winton in , donated more than £m to pro-Remain groups in the EU referendum. In  he was named as a member of the Tory Leader’s Group, offering him the chance to dine with ministers including then-PM Theresa May. But he has also generously helped the party under Brexiteer Boris Johnson, donating almost £, to the Tories since the PM came to power. His gts include a single £, donation a few weeks before the  election.Zac Goldsmith Tory Zac Goldsmith lost his seat in the  election after being trounced by the Liberal Democrats in Richmond Park.But he was swtly handed a le peerage by Boris Johnson so he could serve as Environment Minister in the Lords.The Tory, son of billionaire businessman James Goldsmith, ran in the  London Mayoral election but he was denounced for trying to suggest his Labour rival Sadiq Khan had links to extremists. A long-time ally of the PMaposs we Carrie Johnson, Mr Goldsmith made headlines last year for lending the couple his luxury Marbella villa for a sunshine break.Michael Spencer  The billionaire former treasurer of the Conservative Party was among the  receiving a Tory peerage in July . His firm IPGL Ltd has donated more than £m to the Tories since Boris Johnson became Prime Minister.He was another member of the Tories’ elite ‘Leaders’ Group’, listed as a dinner attendee in early  with either Boris Johnson, Philip Hammond or Theresa May, or all three.The City grandee slammed Theresa May in  for “letting herself down” in her relationship with business, saying the party had been foolish on occasion to adopt some of the language of the socialists”. He later poured money into target seats ahead of the  election landslide. Daniel Moylan  Now Lord Moylan, Daniel Moylan was aviation advisor to Mr Johnson as London Mayor, when he championed a failed plan to build a Thames estuary airport nicknamed Boris Island. The ex-merchant banker and diplomat was ennobled in  alongside several others from the PMaposs City Hall days.He recently went on a bizarre Twitter rant, describing Yorkshire as a county of leftist whingers.His outburst came after the Yorkshire Post reported the governmentaposs levelling up plans were failing to deliver. Posting the front page of the paperaposs weekend edition, the former deputy leader of Kensington and Cha Council said: I’m going to Yorkshire for a short break next week. Everything I’ve read recently in @yorkshirepost makes me fear I’m going to find it transformed into a county of leftist whingers begging for handouts. Let’s hope that’s not the case. Charles Moore  Among those given a peerage in summer  by Boris Johnson was his former boss. Charles Moore, previously said his role at the Dailywas a nightmare because the future PM was always terribly late with his copy. In November  he was at a dinner in London to which the Prime Minister rushed back in a jet from the COP climate summit in Glasgow. Lord Moore has described himself of a climate change sceptic and criticised the repressive hostility from policy elites in an article for thein October. At around the same time, Lord Moore wrote a piece complaining about the “hounding” of Tory MP Owen Paterson, who an inquiry found had breached standards rules. A short time after the dinner, Boris Johnson tried to change Commons rules to save Mr Paterson - leading to outrage and weeks of sleaze headlines. Edward Lister  Another long-time City Hall ally, Eddie Lister was handed a peerage by Boris Johnson in autumn . The -year-old led Tory Wandsworth Council for nearly  years and served as an adviser to Mr Johnson when he was London Mayor.He was brought into No when when Mr Johnson became PM in July  and became acting chief of staff after the dramatic departure of Dominic Cummings in November . Lord Udny-Lister left Government in April .He apologised last year for approving a £million taxpayer-backed loan to a big property developer he was being paid to advise. Geoffrey Cox  Top Conservative Geoffrey Cox – one of Parliament’s biggest earners outside Westminster – was made a Sir in New Year Honours under Boris Johnson. Sir Geoffrey gave up his work as a top-earning QC on being appointed to Cabinet in  - which had previously made him Westminster’s highest paid MP. He vehemently defended Boris Johnson in the Brexit wars and his attacks on the “dead parliament” he inherited from Theresa May. But he later ran into controversy in  when he advised Boris Johnsonaposs government that it was legal to prorogue Parliament - which was later found to be unlawful by the Supreme Court. Sir Geoffrey made headlines in  when it emerged he had tried to claim p for milk before his demand was knocked back by the Parliamentary expenses watchdog. The same year he stood down as the chair of Westminster’s cross-party standards committee, after failing to declare more than £, in outside earnings. He was later ordered to apologise in the Commons for failing to declare the sum within the -day time period. Last year he was embroiled in a second jobs row over his role advising the government of the British Virgin Islands. Tony Gallagher  The multi-millionaire property developer and Tory donor who hosted David Cameronaposs th birthday party was knighted in autumn . He entertained the former Prime Minister at Sarsden House, a listed th-Century Oxfordshire mansion set in  acres which Sir Tony bought for £million in . The entrepreneur is said to be part of the so-called Chipping Norton set centred around the pretty Cotswolds town in the former Tory leaderaposs old Oxfordshire constituency. The two men reportedly came to know one another when Mr Cameron became the local MP and since  Mr Gallagher has donated more than £, to the Conservatives. In , Boris Johnson registered a gt from Mr Gallagher of a sterling silver envelope worth £ following the birth of his son Wilfred. Downing Street said later that the present had been entered on the parliamentary register in error and was being removed as the PM had opted toit. Claire Fox  The former Brexit Party MEP was handed a seat in the Lords in . Once a member of the Revolutionary Communist Party, she was criticised for the groupaposs refusal to condemn the  IRA bombings in Warrington. In  she tweeted in praise of the Liberal Democrats for not taking up peerages - only five years before she joined the House of Lords. Ian Botham  The former England cricketer was given a peerage by Boris Johnson as he marked his first anniversary in No . Lord Botham was reportedly rewarded for his support for Brexit among a list of Eurosceptic loyalists honoured by the PM.He was a high-profile figure pushing for Brexit, branding the EU corrupt and a racket and saying in : Cricket is a game where you achieve the greatest success when you are confident in your own ability to go out and stand proud. Britain has that spirit.He was named as the UKaposs trade envoy to Australia last year. news politics -things-government-snuck-out-"Dominic Raab says Gavin Williamson deserves his knighthoodByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsSince Russia invaded Ukraine two weeks ago more than two million people have fled their homes, according to estimates from the United Nations. The Government has bowed to pressure on its slow humanitarian efforts to help Ukrainian refugees and have planned to launch an online visa application system from Tuesday.Western officials, and even the Prime Minister have expressed their grown concerns that Vladimir Putin is prepared to use chemical weapons in Ukraine. And Ukraine president Volodymyr Zelensky, who has faced a number of assassination attempts, has said he is no longer pressing for Nato membership for Ukraine but made a historic address in the House of Commons. While the Prime Ministeraposs ratings have slightly recovered since the Mirror first published stories on Downing Street lockdown parties, the Government appear to have used the crisis as a time to announce a number of controversial decisions.Here are five things the Tories have snuck out or have been forced to reveal since Russia invaded Ukraine....  Gavin Williamsonaposs knighthoodGavin Williamson, the gaffe-prone Tory who presided over the Covid exams chaos and was sacked by Theresa May as Defence Secretary, was handed the top gong, No confirmed.Ex-No chief of staff Gavin Barwell also claimed last year that Mr Williamson had vowed to unleash “the world’s biggest s**tshow” on the Government when he was fighting for his job as Defence Secretary in . Mr Williamson was sacked as Education Secretary in Boris Johnsonaposs last reshuffle after coming under intense criticism over his handling of the education brief during the pandemic.He came under fire for the  exams chaos and repeated U-turns over free school meals policy, which saw the Government shamed into feeding children over the holidays by footballer Marcus Rashford. He then hit the headlines in September by confusing Rashford with another black sportsman, the rugby player Maro Itoje.  Graduates to pay £, more after student loan shake-upPoorer graduates face paying £, more over their letimes under a major Tory shake-up of student loans. The Institute for Fiscal Studieswarned that Brits on below average incomes would lose out on a higher chunk of their earnings due to changes to student finance rules. Students starting university next year will begin paying off their loans when they earn more than £, - down from the existing £,-a-year threshold. And theof time to repay their debt will be extended to  years, up from . This means some people will still be making repayments into their s. The IFS believes those on lower middle incomes will pay back £, more after revising its estimates in line with inflation rather than average earnings. The reforms would mean that more than halfof students who take out a loan would repay this in full, compared to % currently estimated. Tuition fees will be capped at £, for a further two years, while student loan interest rates will be set no higher than the rate of inflation from  . But the Government quietly rejected the reportaposs key call to slash tuition fees to £,-a-year.  Covid inquiry - terms of reference The Government has finally published its draft terms of reference for the public inquiry into their handling of the Covid pandemic. Boris Johnson announced an inquiry last year after fury at his slow decisions to lock down, which scientists believe cost lives.Retired judge Lady Hallett is set to examine the public health response, how decisions were made, the economic response including the furlough scheme, the procurement of personal protective equipment and even the closure of schools.But the draft Terms of Reference do not name Boris Johnson or promise to look at the inidual behaviour of the Prime Minister. That could come as a blow to bereaved families after ex-aide Dominic Cummings accused him of a litany of failings. Becky Kummer, spokesperson for Covid- Bereaved Families for Justice, said: “The inquiry is a one off and historic opportunity for the terrible suffering and loss of the past two years to be learned from, to ensure these tragedies are not repeated in the future.“The Government finally publishing the draft Terms of Reference is a huge step forward, and we look forward to feeding into the consultation on them. “Sadly, today’s announcement comes far too late. We will never know how many lives could have been saved had the Government had a rapid review phase in Summer , as we called for at the time.  Teachers pay Government proposals to hike salaries for experienced teachers by % in   and % the next year would amount to a pay cut for most staff, teaching unions said.The plans, set out in the official response to the pay review body, would also see new teachers salaries boosted to £,-a-year by  , in line with a Tory manesto commitment.But the union leaders warned that the plans amounted to another signicant real-terms pay cut for most teachers once inflation rates are taken into account.Brits are facing a spiralling cost of living crisis, with inflation rising to .% in January.Public sector pay rises were put on hold in   for all staff except NHS workers and those who earned less than £, due to heavy borrowing during the pandemic. Unused PPE bought during Covid will be burnedThe Government is planning to burn mountains of unusable personal protective equipment bought during the Covid pandemic, MPs have been told.A top Department of Health official said the plan was designed to find somefor . billion pieces of faulty or low quality kit that the NHS cannot use. Around £. billion spent by the Government on useless protective gear was written off by the Government, accounts for   revealed last month.Some £ million worth of equipment was found to be totally unusable, and £ million was spent on items that were not used before their expiry date. Officials are now planning to ship off around , pallets of wasted PPE to power plants to burn each month - around  lorryloads of kit. Rishi Sunak - Partygate questionnaireRishi Sunak joined the list of more than  people to receive a questionnaire from the Met Police to explain any involvement in gatherings at Downing Street.It’s understood the Chancellor received the form, which needed to be ed within seven days as requested by Scotland Yard. The Met is looking into  alleged gatherings held across Whitehall and Downing Street during lockdown rules under Operation Hillman.Mr Sunak previously confirmed he was at Boris Johnson ’s birthday do, held by No staff and the PM’s we Carrie on June , . But he insisted he had been present at the Cabinet Room for a routine meeting to discuss Covid. Earlier this month, he appeared to suggest he was not expecting to receive a form to complete. Asked on Sky News earlier this monthhe expected to receive a form, he replied: No... well, I donapost know. title: acts kindness british people stark
story: Acts of kindness by British people are a stark contrast to Tory refugee apathyBrian Reade says that whatever schemes they now come up with to distract from their initial response to the victims of Putins war, Tories have shamed Britain into looking small, nasty and cruelFamilies are reunited as Ukrainian refugees cross the border to Dorohusk Image: Adam Gray SWNSopinionByBrian Reade:,  Mar |comments Last weekend a mate told me he was driving over to Poland to deliver emergency supplies to Ukrainian refugees.He had nothing to give them at the time but was putting out an appeal for cash on social media and aiming to stock up at a hypermarket near the Ukraine border. Brendan Wyatt, who owns Liverpool clothing store Transalpino, had no experience of the aid industry, but after seeing the harrowing scenes of fleeing women and children, and our ­government’s pitul response to it, he couldn’t just sit back and watch. He left last weekend with his mate Robin Grime and Rado Chmiel, a Pole living in Liverpool, as interpreter. When they reached Rzeszow close to the Ukraine border, they went to a Macro store and filled a hired van full of food, blankets, nappies, sanitary towels, kids’ shoes and toys bought with the £, they had raised en route.  They then drove to a refuge centre and handed the much-needed supplies over to  grateful and humbled women and children. When I asked Brendan why he made the trip, he answered “because I could”. He is just one of countless British citizens, moved by the haunting plight of desperate Ukrainians, doing their bit to help, whether giving money, volunteering with charities or heading there to fight. But while we’re witnessing sacrice, generosity and action from below, at the top we’re seeing coldness, indference and mental torture by bureaucracy. Krzysztof Mikucki, a builder who drove from Mansfield to the Romanian border to pick up his Ukrainian we and her mother, and drive them back to safety in Britain, was one of hundreds held up for hours by UK Border Force staff at Calais and eventually told to go to Brussels or Paris to apply for a visa. “They treated us worse than the water in the toilet,” he said, angrily.  Refugees who have tried to come here to escape Putin’s genocide speak of our government treating them like criminals. And sadly they are spot-on. Because the Home Office’s lamentable excuse for not acting in the same humane manner as virtually every other European nation and greeting them with open arms is that we have to be sure these people are not spies or terrorists. Even though they are distraught women and children who have been battered out of their homes and are now battered with red tape to keep them out of the UK.How did we reach the point where the greeting from a once-compassionate country to ­families ­travelling , miles to fleethe worst nightmare imaginable is a taped-up piece of A paper on a Calais hostel window sending them back  miles to Paris or ­Brussels How was there no one in authority ­apologising and explaining what was going on, despite this ­effectively being the UK border with Europe   Meanwhile, in the Commons, the liar-in-chief and his immigrant-hating sidekicks shed ­crocodile tears and talk about Britain having an unparalleled tradition for welcoming refugees. Well we did before electing a government primarily on a ticket to shut our borders to outsiders. And whatever schemes they now come up with to distract from their initial response to the victims of Putin’s obscene war, these Tories have shamed Britain into looking small, insular, mean, nasty and cruel. Even though so many of its people are the polar opposite. title: british schools preparing welcome 100000
story: British schools preparing to welcome , Ukrainian refugee childrenEducation Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said plans were being drawn up to welcome refugees fleeing Vladimir Putins invasion, with online lessons in Russian and UkrainianBoy rests on bag as people fleeing war-torn Ukraine arrive on a train from Poland in Berlin Image: Getty ImagesByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Mar |commentsBritish schools are preparing to admit , Ukrainian refugees, with online lessons available in translation, the Education Secretary has said. Nadhim Zahawi, who fled to Britain as a child from Iraq, said plans were being drawn up to welcome children fleeing the Russian invasion.He said auto-translate software was being rolled out on online learning hub Oak National Academy to help pupils who speak Russian or Ukrainian. Pupils will be able to access quizzes, video lessons with translated subtitles and worksheets. The UK Government has been under intense pressure to do more to help Ukrainians fleeing the brutal conflict after the visa process descended into chaos.  Ukrainians with family ties to Britain can apply for visas but families have reported delays and excessive bureaucracy - with some arriving in Calais only to be sent to visa centres in Brussels or Paris. The Government is expected to set out further details on a separate sponsorship route on Monday, where Brits will be able to host refugees in their own homes. Speaking at the Association of School and College Leadersconference, Mr Zahawi said: We will continue to support Ukrainians in any way we can. I know schools are doing what they can to support their students make sense of what they are seeing. And we are working with schools to ensure that the tens of thousands of Ukrainian children we will welcome to our shores will have a place in our education system. A team in the Department for Education is already making plans for a capacity of , children that we will take into our schools, he said but did not give further details. Mr Zahawi added: The family reunion route will be a couple of hundred thousand people coming through and then the humanitarian route which Michael Gove will outline in the next few days, will be uncapped.He branded the Russian aggression as barbaric, criminal invasion of their sovereign democratic country and said it was almost impossible to imagine the horror of what they are going through. I came here many of you will know aged  unable to string a sentence of English together...even the thought of going to school was really scary, he added. Andmy teacher...hadnapost reminded me to funnel some of that creative, disruptive energy into something good, I certainly wouldnapost be here today. news politics brits-need-fourth-dose-covid-"Javid says fourth dose of Covid jab is ‘under review’ByJosh PayneIsobel FrodshamKieren Williams:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsHealth Secretary Sajid Javid has said that the rollout of a fourth Covid vaccine dose is being ‘kept under review’ amid rising cases in the UK.Javid said that ministers would continue to follow advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation , after figures showed a spike in infection rates in all four home nations. He spoke out during a visit to Birmingham Children’s Hospital today when he was asked whether he intended to bring forward a fourth booster shot. He said: When it comes to vaccinations and any future vaccinations, we listen carefully to what our expert advisers have to say in the JCVI. They have said recently... that certainly for groups of people, the over-s, immunosuppressed, those in residential care homes, they will receive a second booster shot... a fourth dose, and that will begin in the coming weeks.  We are preparing for that, and that will be recommended for those that have had at least a six-month gap between that dose and their previous one. When pushed further, he added: We keep it under review, but the right thing to do is to listen to the expert advice... Iaposm very confident with our approach. In February last month, Mr Javid said that the most vulnerable and at risk groups would receive a fourth dose in coming weeks. This was to help ensure they maintained a high-enough level of protection against the deadly virus.  Those who are eligible will be offered the jab around six months after their last dose. The latest figures have shown that, for the first time since the end of January, all four home nations have seen week-on-week spikes in infections.Figures published by the ONS infection survey show that, across the UK as a whole, . million people were estimated to have coronavirus last week. That number stood at . million at the start of the year, however this is a rise from . million.Mr Javid said the Government was continuing to monitor the situation very carefully in response to a rise in Covid- infections among the elderly and in childrenaposs hospitals.Obviously we monitor the situation regularly, we keep it under review, but at this stage things are very steady as we learn to live with Covid, he said. It does underline the importance of the defences we have built. Getting vaccinated, particularlyyou havenapost been vaccinated already, is very important. Whilst itaposs great to see, when it comes to the boosters, eight out of  adults have had their booster shots, those two out of  that have not yet come forward - itaposs still a very good time to come forward. title: labour tackle educational elitism giving
story: Exclusive: Labour to tackle educational elitism giving state school kids top creative teachersBridget Phillipson is set to deliver her debut speech as Shadow Education Secretary on Saturday, unveiling details of a national excellence programme that will give state school kids a rounded education Image: Getty ImagesByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsLabour will unveil ambitious plans to tackle elitism that exists within Britainaposs education system - giving state school pupils access to top-tier Creative Arts teachers. Currently, more than , English secondary schools employ A level teachers without the qualications to teach Music and Drama at that level subjects that are widely considered accessible for the privileged few. Bridget Phillipson, in her debut speech as Shadow Education Secretary, is expected to back parentsapos priorities, and give every child a rounded, fulfilling education on all subjects - including creative ones. She will reject “ choices” between prioritising academic and creative education, arguing that creativity, collaboration and problem solving promoted through sport and drama are as essential to the skills and jobs of the future. Ms Phillipson will say in Birmingham: As children grow up … school becomes more, not less, narrow. And that narrowing turns too many young people off learning which is a problem for their future and all of our futures.  We must retain the breadth. “I make no apology for being determined to see young people achieve academically, and just as important I want to see them thrive in le. It comes after former Schools Minister Nick Gibb revealed  state schools did not employ an A Level music teacher with such qualications and , with the relevant drama qualications. Creative subjects have seen huge declines in teacher numbers, with drama and music seeing declines of around %, according to official data. Ms Phillipson will add: “Knowledge is essential, but so is the ability to apply that rich knowledge to the real world, ensuring young people learn communication, collaboration and problem solving skills, and understand the dference they can make.“That is why Keir Starmer has announced Labour ’s Council of Skills Advisors to support us in ensuring every young person receives a rounded education that instils a love of learning and equips them with the skills they need for work and for le.” Labour has vowed to recruit , new teachers as part of its national excellence programme. Under a decade of Conservative government rule, fewer British kids choose to pursue creative subjects at GCSE like Music and Drama. The number of youngsters taking Drama and Music subjects at GCSE has slumped by more than % from  , to   with , taking the subjects last year. With more teachers, the party believes it can tackle the shortage of teachers which leaves some schools without the expertise to give every child a rounded, fulfilling education.The Shadow Education Secretaryaposs speech comes as data from the Institute for Public Policy Research, shows parents are increasingly prioritising their children’s enjoyment of learning and understanding of the world around them. Londonaposs prestigious Royal Academy of Music has previously revealed less than half of its pupils starting undergraduate degrees came from state schools in . The UKaposs top violinist Nigel Kennedy once vowed to drum out elitism within music education as he feared the subject had only become accessible to the privileged few. For me, the cause of this dumbing down is a natural rebellion against the ill-informed classical music administrators who consciously encourage exclusivity, refusing to embrace those outside their spectacularly precious world, he said.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Labour PartyJess PhillipsEducationSchoolsPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tory government rakes 264m selling
story: Exclusive: Tory government rakes in £m selling off magistrates courts despite record backlogNew figures show ministers have sold off  court buildings out of  since the Tories came to power in  as part of cost cutting measures Image: Daily MirrorByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  Mar |commentsThe Tories have made a £million killing flogging off magistrates courts - despite the record backlog of cases because of Covid.. Ministers got the most cash for London’s Camberwell Green court at £.million - and the least for the th Century one at Ely, Cambs which the city council bought for just £ so it could relocate there. New figures show ministers have sold off  court buildings out of  since the Tories came to power in  as part of cost cutting measures. Yet because of the pandemic magistrates courts are taking nearly three months to hear cases and the crown court backlog will not be cleared until . Shadow Justice Secretary Steve Reed said: “This soft-on-crime Conservative Government have brought about record delays in our courts because of these short-sighted selloffs. “Victims are waiting years for their day in court while criminals aren’t brought to justice. The Conservatives are letting criminals off and letting victims down.”  As buildings were sold cases were switched to nearby courts, though critics say this has increased journey times and makes it dficult for single mums and the disabled to get there. The courts went to private buyers, property developers and local authorities Rochdale court was sold for £, to the trustees of a mosque and London’s Bow County Court for £.million to an evangelical mission. The Ministry of Justice says the courts closed were underused and £million from sales have been reinvested to introduce new technology and online services.Justice minister James Cartlidge added: “The decision to close any court is not taken lightly. “It only happens following full public consultation and only when effective access to justice can be maintained.” But former Justice Secretary Robert Buckland blamed delays in hearing cases on budget cuts as well as Covid. Extra Nightingale courts were introduced during the pandemic to increase the capacity. title: uk should not putting obstacles
story: UK should not be putting obstacles between Ukrainian refugees and visasWriting for the Sunday Mirror, Tory MP Caroline Nokes warns: "You simply cannot run an ordinary immigration system in such extraordinary times" Image: Getty ImagesopinionByCaroline Nokes:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsImagine you are a Ukrainian fleeing the war. Your home has been bombed, you have just lost everything and you’re carrying the few possession you have left in a plastic bag. You know generous Brits want to welcome you to the safety of our shores. But first you have to navigate the bureaucracy. Currently to get here you have to fill in a complex visa application form. A friend of mine did it on behalf of a Ukrainian refugee and it took her three hours. My friend is intelligent, British, so a native English speaker, and has not just been frightened out of her wits by a Russian invasion. Yet even she struggled. While I welcome the decision to allow holders of Ukrainian passports to apply online for a visa without having to submit biometrics, surely this week the Home Office must announce plans to make it much easier Ukrainians without a biometric passport will still have to travel to a Visa Application Centre to submit fingerprints and we have seen the chaos at these centres where few appointments are available. A single online application for a whole family, rather than each inidual, would make the process both easier and more efficient. And it would be kinder to children. We should be issuing visas as quickly as possible, not putting obstacles in the way of getting people to safety.. You simply cannot run an ordinary immigration system in such extraordinary times. story: Cheeky great-gran credits Jägerbombs, tequila  pizza for making nd birthdayLily Bullen recently celebrated her nd birthday, but despite her old age, she still loves a good knees-up and chooses to mark every birthday with a tequila shotByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Mar |comments A tequila-loving great-grandmother has shared her own personal secrets for how sheaposs made it to celebrating her nd birthday - and it sounds like an awful lot of fun.Lily Bullen recently celebrated her birthday with family and friends, with her usual party trick of downing a shot of tequila, which she says helps her to love her le.Despite making it to age that most of us will never reach, Lily is still full of le and loves treating herself with Dominoaposs pizza, Greggs sausage rolls and cream cakes.Still one for adventure, on her th birthday Lily even tried ice-skating for the first time, and sheaposll never turn down a good knees-up.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Party-loving Lily, who has three grown-up children, five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren, says the secret to longevity is to enjoy le. title: i could always tell kids
story: I could always tell when my kids were lying - so I became top private investigatorSharon Sutila, , from the US, says her kids stopped trying to lie to her after realising she would always suss them out - so she decided to turn her skills into a successful careerSharon says her kids dont bother lying to her anymore as they know theyll be found out Image: PA Real LeByJoe PagnelliJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsA mum who became an expert in detecting the fibs of her children says itaposs given her the skills she needed to become a top private investigator. Sharon Sutila, , is a mum-of-two with a sixth sense for when people are telling porkies - something she claims to have learned from raising -year-old Marissa and -year-old Tesla. Now the CEO of Cluso Investigation, which she founded in , Sharon puts her super sleuth skills to work uncovering secrets people would rather keep buried. Sharon, who describes herself as a human lie detector, says her kids donapost even bother lying to her anymore, as they know theyaposll get caught. The mum from the US state of Delaware said: My skillset means I stay as neutral as I can, evenI don’t trust what they are telling me. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here I don’t call them out, I try to stay cool and find outthey are telling me the truth, but I always find out. They are aware of that, so they have grown up knowing it is always better to tell the truth. If theyaposve ever told me they don’t have homework when they do, they know I will find out about it.She described an incident when Marissa was little and she tried to conceal a mark sheaposd made in the house from her mum. Sharon says she not only found out about the mark, but also went as far as showing her daughter the New York state laws to let her know lying has consequences. She said: I think it scared her to death!  The mum reckons she honed her detective skills when she was just  years old and channelled her favourite literary characters, Sherlock Holmes and Nancy Drew. After a classroom bully smashed her favourite record and wrote her a nasty note, Sharon was determined to expose them to her teacher. She found out who the culprit was by comparing their handwriting to the homework of her peers. After graduating from university in , Sharon shunned the family business in fishing and seafood to embark upon a career in tech for IBM. There, she realised she could use her coding skills to suss out new potential employees - and she pointed out those who werenapost telling the truth on their CVs.  People had put degrees that they had never taken and qualications that they never had, she said. And when her bosses discovered her skills, she became an integral part of the companyaposs international operation. Sharon said: I wanted to know more about the person, or I couldn’t be sure they weren’t lying to me. I absolutely love research, figuring things out and problem solving. I like challenges. Now working as a private investigator, Sharon says sheaposs skilled at finding out things about people from the comfort of her own home - as long as she has a computer. She said: I mostly work on allowing people to tell me what they want to tell me first. And I’ll try to seethey are being honest.  While Sharon enjoys her work, sheaposs had to put up with her fair share of threats from people who sheaposs exposed. She said: I have been threatened. A man told me he was going to come into my house. But I’m not going to let someone stop me from doing my job just because they are being aggressive. I’m not going to stop what I do because of a threat. Sharon has now penned a novel based on some of her experiences working in a male-dominated industry, called The Healing. She said: Championing equality for women is my lelong passion. Challenging gender bias and the stereotyping of women is critically important to combat the issue. I wrote my book by starting my character with a lot of my own background. I grew up in the same time frame as the book and went through the very same gender norms, which can mean women canapost do or achieve certain things. In the book, the character starts in the same way I did - being told I couldnapost follow my own path. And she is trying to find her purpose in the world. Sharonaposs top  signs someone might be lying: . If someone uses the word aposhonestlyapos they might be hiding something. . If people who start to over-explain situations - the truth is often much simpler. . If someone is immediately defensive or turns to anger when they are asked a question. . If someone knows too much about a subject, as liars will often do research. . If people react strangely when you tell them you are going to check the information they have given you.Do you have a story to share  Email jesssica.taylor@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Sherlock HolmesParenting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
